block.p: International A3-19
International A3-19
APPEAL TO CONGRESS ON BOSNIA President Clinton appealed to Congress to support sending American troops as peacemakers to Bosnia, showing the importance he attaches to Congressional backing. A1
FROM CLINTON: NO TURNING BACK President Clinton's Bosnia policy has been through an uncertain odyssey, but he has made it clear that he now feels there is no turning back. News analysis. A18
In a Georgia city, skepticism for the President's plan. A19
On Capitol Hill, looking back to history for precedents. A18
An agreement from Russia on sending peacekeepers. A18
BREAKTHROUGH ON ULSTER PEACE Britain and Ireland reached a compromise over the Irish Republican Army role in negotiations that should allow peace talks for Northern ireland to go forward. A1

CHINA GLOBAL WARMING THREAT China's use of coal for energy, combined with its vastly increasing consumer economy, is posing a major threat that contributes to the warming of the earth's atmosphere. A1
CIRCUS SMUGGLING ACT A circus in Zimbabwe that has been traveling through Africa is said by animal rights activists to be a front for a smuggling operation in endangered species. Harare journal. A1
NEW POLAND LEADER ON HIS IMAGE The President-elect of Poland, in an interview, said it is wrong to think of him as a former Communist and that he is a social democrat seeking privatization. A3
JAPAN REDUCES MILITARY Japan plans to reduce its military although it has asked the United States not to reduce troop strength in Japan, despite much opposition from the Japanese public. A9
An American-owned newspaper settled a Singapore suit. A10
Elections point to the widening rift in Egypt. A7
For Chernobyl victims, trouble continues but a trust fund is dry. A11
Guerrillas in Lebanon raised tension, firing rockets into Israel. A6
In Rio, a huge demonstration to protest crime. A15 National
DRUG MAKER'S GUILTY PLEA Warner-Lambert pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to pay $10 million for hiding from the F.D.A. faulty manufacturing processes used for several drugs. A1

SHOWDOWN SEEMS CERTAIN A former executive of Brown & Williamson, Jeffrey Wigands, seemed to be on a collision course with the tobacco company after a Mississippi court cleared the way for him to give a deposition despite a restraining order against the action issued by Kentucky court. A20

LOOKING FOR NEW LIFE Built in the mountains of north central New Mexico to build the atomic bomb, Los Alamos is trying to transform itself into a tourist attraction like Taos as a way of overcoming the slowdown of Government spending. A20

CONGRESS TACKLES SPENDING With each of the last spending bills facing holdups because of one or two difficult issues that could derail important negotiations, Congress is turning to the last of those spending bills. B10

UNION ORGANIZERS PROTECTED Upholding a policy of the National Labor Relations Board, the Supreme Court held that employers may not retaliate against union organizers or refuse to hire applicants they suspect may be interested in such organization. B11
AID FOR CHARITIES In a bipartisan agreement, the House passed a measure to exempt charities from the antitrust and securities that apply to businesses and the Senate is expected to follow suit. B13

I.R.S. BEATS A RETREAT After a report that the I.R.S. was considering treating frequent-flier miles that are given to employees by companies as taxable income for the individuals, the tax agency said it had no plans to do so. B14
Education D20
More and more, older students are now turning to home-schooling. Metro Digest B1

PLOTTING IN SQUALOR? In the last year, city officials have evacuated almost 200 people from dungeonlike cellars in Chinatown. But housing officials now suspect some of the emergencies were a hoax, and that the horrific living conditions were a ruse for immigrants to get city housing. A1

ON WELFARE, WORKING IN SCHOOLS Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is pushing the use of welfare recipients to supervise students during lunchtime, at recess and in hallways when they change classes and before and after school, duties that teachers will no longer have to perform under a new contract worked out with City Hall. A1
Business Digest D1
Arts/Entertainment C13-18

Vermeer show in Washington. C13 The New-York Historical Society is still in financial difficulty. C13 Film: "When Billy Broke His Head . . . and Other Tales of Wonder." C17 Music: Mandy Patinkin. C14 Books: C. C. O'Brien's "On the Eve of the Millennium." C17 Television: "Rod Serling: Submitted for Your Approval." C13 Celebrity cameos. C18
Health Page C10 Personal Health: Air bags save lives, but not always. Psychotherapy or drugs for depression? New findings. When negative expectations make you sick.
Obituaries D19

Sports B15-20 Baseball: Cone unsure on Yank future. B15 Isringhausen optimistic. B17 Basketball: Nelson's approach working. B15 Column: Araton on St. John's coach B15 Football: Lions could loom for Reeves. B15 Murrell delivers for Jets. B19 Hockey: Robitaille cools heels. B19 Tennis: Davis Cup final without Agassi. B17
Editorials/Op-Ed A22-23

Editorials What happened to Elisa? Just say no, Mr. Dole. For reconciliation in Algeria. Lincoln Center's festival. Letters Thomas L. Friedman: Why and how. Frank Rich: Hillary Clinton, R.I.P. Coreen Costello: Giving up my baby. Jeffrey D. Sachs: Why corruption rules Russia.
